content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple fragments of tissue. There are approximately 10-12 ovoid, darkly stained purple structures that are characteristic of lymph nodes. Some of these nodes appear entirely replaced by tumor, while others seem partially involved or reactive. There is also a larger, more complex tissue section in the upper left, which likely represents the primary colorectal tumor with surrounding adipose tissue. The overall impression is of a lymph node dissection and a section of the primary tumor from a colorectal cancer resection specimen.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this area because this particular tissue fragment, located on the lower left, has a different morphology compared to the other fragments that clearly appear to be lymph nodes. It exhibits a more organized, glandular or mucosal pattern even at low magnification. It is crucial to identify all pieces of tissue on the slide. This could be a fragment of the primary tumor, normal colonic mucosa from a resection margin, a separate polyp, or a lymph node completely effaced by a well-differentiated tumor. Clarifying its identity is essential for accurate staging and diagnosis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the periphery of one of the larger lymph nodes located in the lower-left portion of the image. The zoom target is the area directly beneath the lymph node capsule. This region, which includes the subcapsular sinus, is the first and most common site where metastatic tumor cells lodge after arriving via afferent lymphatic vessels. It is standard practice to carefully examine the entire subcapsular sinus of each lymph node to detect even small metastatic deposits (micrometastases). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to systematically evaluate every lymph node for evidence of metastasis, as this is critical for staging (N staging). The area indicated by the green box is a distinct, well-circumscribed, basophilic nodule, characteristic of a lymph node. It is located on the left side of the slide, just below the large primary tumor section. I am zooming into this specific lymph node as part of a sequential review of all submitted nodes to assess its architecture and cellular composition at higher magnification. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is located at the periphery of one of the largest and most cellular lymph nodes in the image (the large, centrally located node). This specific location, at the interface between the lymph node parenchyma and the surrounding adipose tissue, is critical for assessing the lymph node capsule. The primary reason for this examination is to look for evidence of extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of tumor cells through the lymph node capsule into the perinodal fat. The presence of ENE is a significant adverse prognostic factor, and its identification is a key part of the pathological report. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the task is to examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The green box is placed on one of the larger lymph nodes. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic review of all submitted nodes. A closer look is necessary to evaluate the node's architecture, including the subcapsular sinus, cortex, and medulla, and to search for any atypical cell clusters that would be indicative of metastatic carcinoma, which cannot be reliably identified at this low magnification. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every piece of tissue that resembles a lymph node to search for metastatic disease. The highlighted area is one of these lymph node candidates. It is the second distinct lymph node-like structure from the top of the slide. I am zooming into this specific area to assess its architecture and cellular composition at high magnification to either confirm or rule out the presence of metastatic carcinoma, which is critical for determining the patient's cancer stage (N stage). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The green box is placed on the periphery of one of the smaller lymph nodes located in the upper central part of the slide. I am zooming into this specific area because the subcapsular sinus and the interface with the perinodal fat are common initial sites for metastatic tumor deposits. It is crucial to carefully inspect the capsule and the surrounding tissue for any small clusters of atypical cells or extracapsular extension. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is one of the potential lymph nodes that needs to be assessed for metastasis. Specifically, the zoom is targeted at the periphery of the lymph node, at the interface between the lymphoid tissue and the surrounding perinodal fat. This is a critical area to examine because metastatic tumor cells typically arrive via afferent lymphatics and first deposit in the subcapsular sinus, which is located just beneath the lymph node capsule. Examining this junction is a systematic way to screen for early metastatic deposits and to check for extranodal extension (tumor breaking through the capsule into the fat). This particular lymph node is located in the lower-middle portion of the slide. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every lymph node on the slide to search for evidence of metastasis. The selected area is one of these lymph nodes. At low power, it appears as a well-defined nodule of dense lymphoid tissue. I need to zoom in to high power to assess the cellular architecture and cytology to differentiate between a benign reactive process (e.g., follicular hyperplasia) and the presence of malignant metastatic cells, which can be subtle. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to screen every lymph node for evidence of cancer spread (metastasis). The lymph node highlighted by the green box (the fourth distinct node from the top on the right side) shows an abnormal, solid, dark purple appearance, suggesting that its normal architecture might be replaced by tumor cells. I am zooming into this specific area to get a high-power view of the cells to confirm if they are indeed malignant epithelial cells, which would classify this as a positive lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to systematically examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The area indicated by the green box is one of the candidate lymph nodes. I would zoom into this area, and every other similar-looking structure, to assess its architecture and cellular composition at high magnification. The goal is to determine if normal lymphoid tissue is present or if it has been replaced by malignant cells from the primary colorectal cancer. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my procedure is to examine every lymph node. The area indicated by the green box is one of these potential lymph nodes, specifically the uppermost one on the right. At low magnification, this node appears almost entirely replaced by a dense, dark blue cell population, losing the typical architecture of a benign lymph node (e.g., distinct cortex and medulla, germinal centers). This uniform, solid appearance is highly suspicious for metastatic disease, requiring a high-power examination to confirm the presence and nature of the infiltrating cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is located on the largest lymph node in the upper right portion of the slide. Pathological examination requires assessing every lymph node. I chose this specific spot on the periphery of the node because the interface between the dense lymphoid tissue and the surrounding connective/adipose tissue appears irregular. The subcapsular sinus, located just under the capsule, is often the first site where metastatic cells deposit, making the periphery a high-yield area for detecting metastasis. This area looks suspicious for capsular invasion or extranodal extension. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I see a piece of colonic mucosa. The right side of the fragment shows well-preserved colonic crypts, which appear relatively normal with straight, parallel glands and abundant goblet cells. The left side of the fragment shows an area of ulceration. The surface epithelium is lost and replaced by granulation tissue, which consists of inflammatory cells, fibrin, and new blood vessels. My impression is that this is a fragment of colonic mucosa with surface ulceration. This could represent the edge of the primary ulcerative tumor or an unrelated inflammatory process. There is no definitive evidence of invasive carcinoma in this specific field of view.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image shows the edge of a lymph node. On the right, I can identify the pink, fibrous lymph node capsule with some adjacent adipose (fat) cells. The area immediately under the capsule is the subcapsular sinus. The rest of the field is filled with a dense population of small, round, dark-staining cells, which are lymphocytes. I do not see any atypical cells, nests of tumor cells, or glandular structures within the subcapsular sinus or the underlying lymphoid cortex in this specific view. My impression of this field is that it is a benign/reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis. I would proceed to scan the rest of the node's periphery and its entirety to confirm this finding.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a section of a lymph node. The overall architecture appears preserved with recognizable lymphoid follicles and interfollicular regions. The node is composed predominantly of a dense population of small lymphocytes. There are some dilated sinuses containing eosinophilic proteinaceous material and scattered histiocytes (sinus histiocytosis), which is a reactive change. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular formations, or large nests of tumor cells that would indicate metastasis. My impression of this specific field is a reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy. The entire node would need to be examined to confirm this finding.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see a dense, solid sheet of malignant-appearing cells (dark purple) on the top portion of the image, which have completely replaced the normal lymph node architecture. The lower portion of the image shows mature adipose tissue (fat cells). Critically, there is no distinct fibrous capsule separating the tumor mass from the fat. Instead, the tumor cells are seen directly infiltrating the adipose tissue. This observation confirms the presence of extranodal extension (ENE). Therefore, my impression is that this is a lymph node completely effaced by metastatic carcinoma, with clear evidence of extranodal extension.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a section of a lymph node with preserved, albeit altered, architecture. There are multiple lymphoid follicles. Some follicles show prominent, reactive-appearing germinal centers. Other follicles have atrophic, hyalinized germinal centers and prominent, concentrically arranged lymphocytes in the mantle zone, a feature sometimes described as 'onion-skinning'. These features are characteristic of reactive follicular hyperplasia, with some areas showing changes reminiscent of hyaline-vascular Castleman disease. I do not see any definite nests of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or desmoplastic stromal reaction to suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field is a reactive lymph node with no evidence of malignancy.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a section of a lymph node. The overall architecture shows reactive changes, with some preserved lymphoid follicles visible at the bottom. The bulk of the tissue consists of a dense, monotonous population of small lymphocytes. I am carefully looking for clusters of atypical cells, abnormal gland formation, or extracellular mucin, which would be features of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma. In this specific field of view, I do not see any convincing evidence of metastatic tumor cells. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 7. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a collection of small, dark, round cells with scant cytoplasm, which are morphologically consistent with benign lymphocytes. These lymphocytes are located at the edge of a lymphoid aggregate, directly abutting mature adipose tissue. I do not see any atypical cells, such as cells with large irregular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, or glandular formation, that would be suspicious for metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field of view is that it shows benign lymphoid tissue at the interface with fat, with no evidence of malignancy.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see the edge of a lymph node. The left side of the image shows a dense, monotonous population of small, round lymphocytes with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm, which is characteristic of normal lymphoid parenchyma. The right side shows mature adipose tissue (fat cells). A thin, pink, fibrous capsule separates the lymphoid tissue from the fat. The subcapsular sinus, the space just beneath the capsule, is visible. In this specific field, there are no atypical epithelial cells, tumor nests, or glandular structures to suggest metastatic carcinoma. The impression for this specific field of view is a benign/reactive lymph node. However, a definitive conclusion requires a thorough examination of the entire lymph node and all other nodes on the slide.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a dense, diffuse proliferation of small, dark, round cells with scant cytoplasm, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. I do not see any definite nests, glands, or clusters of atypical epithelial cells with large, irregular nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The overall appearance is that of a dense lymphoid infiltrate, most consistent with a reactive lymph node (e.g., follicular hyperplasia). My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 10 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, the normal architecture of the lymph node is largely effaced. I see dense sheets of lymphoid cells, but infiltrated by irregular nests and glands of atypical epithelial cells. These invading cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei, and are forming poorly-defined glandular structures. This is a classic presentation of metastatic adenocarcinoma within a lymph node. My impression is definitive for a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 11 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see that the normal architecture of the lymph node is almost completely effaced. It is replaced by dense, back-to-back sheets and clusters of malignant cells. These cells have large, hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei and a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm, forming poorly-defined glandular structures. These features are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The lymph node is surrounded by adipose tissue. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, extensively infiltrated by metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 12 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a dense, monotonous proliferation of cells arranged in solid sheets, completely effacing the normal lymph node structure. The cells are highly atypical, with large, hyperchromatic (darkly stained), and pleomorphic (variably shaped) nuclei, and scant cytoplasm. There is no gland formation, which suggests a poorly differentiated carcinoma. My impression is that this is a lymph node completely replaced by metastatic, poorly differentiated carcinoma. This is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 13 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, on the right, there is a dense sheet of lymphocytes, characteristic of lymph node parenchyma. On the left, there is perinodal adipose tissue and fibrous capsular tissue. The key finding is the infiltration of the capsule and the edge of the lymphoid parenchyma by atypical cells. These cells are arranged in nests and poorly formed glands. They are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, with pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei and a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm. My impression is that this represents metastatic adenocarcinoma infiltrating the lymph node. The presence of tumor cells in the pericapsular fibrous and adipose tissue is indicative of extranodal extension.
